"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545d829763687274df0d0200#post_545d829763687274df0d0200

 Goods are available and distributed at the same monetary rate everywhere. "Buy Low, Sell High" doesn't apply in such a place. Prices are fixed in such a way that it is impossible to make money by buying something and then re-selling it elsewhere.

This becomes a problem in these situations:

    1) Try to make a profit in this immovable market.

    2) The only way to earn money if speculation is unprofitable, upgrading equipment becomes dangerous. 

This can also, ironically, overlap when there is both a single price no matter where you go and that price rises as you move along.

There's a thing called "The Law of One-Price".

[spoiler]You have three spirits. God as a beggar who shows him a reflection into his past on some passages. The Devil as a charro who promises him more riches and physical power. Then as you well mentioned, Death as just a passenger, but whom Macario feels a connection to because he knew he would not come back and the chicken wasn't meant to appease his hunger but rather as a reward of his family for all hi did for them.

Unlike Scrooge who learned humbleness and being kind to your fellow men, Macario is instead a more down to earth individual and the perfect couterpart. He's already aware of those things and also accepts his own mortality, he knows everything has an end and all what's left is to embrace that and not think of death as an enemy.[/spoiler]

"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545d86be63687232dfb70100#post_545d86be63687232dfb70100

It's not really cheatting as much as trying to work around the system to gain an advantage in to what otherwise would be a no win situation. Ideallistically, every person wins and loses in an investement on equal measure. Remember we as individuals value short terms answers and results above everything.
